transcripts.text: Okay, we're ready.  This week we saw democracy in chaos in Wisconsin as the governor postponed in person voting to keep Wisconsin voters safe and then A court overturned the ruling.  Let's see what the President of the United States thought about that.

Mr.  President, there's voting going on today in Wisconsin.  There are reports of thousands of people waiting in hours-long lines as they've had to weigh their own personal health and their civic responsibility.  Do you think that the Supreme Court was right in its decision that voting should go forward and the absentee extension should take place?
Look, the Supreme Court, of course they were right.

To be clear, he's saying he thinks it was right that people in Wisconsin had to choose between their own health and their right to vote.  Who will be responsible and who should be held responsible if people get sick after they voted?

All I did was endorse a candidate.  I don't know anything about their lines.  I don't know anything about their voting.  All of a sudden, they want safety.  Well, before I did the endorsement, they didn't talk about safety.  It was fine for months.  For months, it was fine.  It was always going to be.  And now I endorse and they want safety.

So yes, for months, holding an in-person election was safe.  Then a pandemic happened.  Why did you feel it was necessary to still come out and cast your vote?  I'm a voter and we have to get out and vote.  That's why I propose making the government invest in making our in-person voters safer.  Democrats, Republicans, Independents, make everyone safer and offer online registration, vote by mail, and extended early voting.  So you were highly critical of mail-in voting, mail-in ballots for voting.
I think mail-in voting is horrible.
It's corrupt.  But you voted by mail in Florida's election last month, didn't you?
Sure, I could vote by mail because I'm allowed to.
So let me get this straight.  You support vote by mail when it's convenient for you.

I've gotten letters from folks all across the country who are worried about what this means for our democracy.  So let's just hear from a few of them.  Paul from Colorado writes, We are fortunate in Colorado to have vote by mail.  I've been voting by mail for years, and I sincerely hope Congress is able to overcome Republican obstructionism and voter suppression to allow everyone to vote by mail.  Thanks.  You've had the firsthand experience with it.  And here's Tom from Wisconsin.  My 85-year-old parents are going to have to risk their lives to go to the polls here in Wisconsin on April 7th because they refuse to postpone.  I get it, Tom.  This isn't right and it is not a choice anyone should have to make.  Mitch McConnell should call the Senate back in session so we can get to work.  Americans are in crisis and we must do everything we can to provide relief.  Relief to students, relief to our seniors, relief to our small business owners.  And we must protect our democracy.  I've got a plan to make in-person voting safer and to offer citizens the option to vote by mail and early vote.  Go to ElizabethWarren.com to learn more and join us.
